Job Opportunities

Research Assistant, Research: City Leader Guide on Distressed Properties

The Bloomberg Harvard City Leadership Initiative is currently seeking Research Assistants for Fall 2021 and the 2021 - 2022 academic year.

These graduate student Research Assistant opportunities are paid positions, for varying lengths of time, depending on the project. Ideal candidates for Research Assistant positions demonstrate strong written and verbal communication skills, possess an entrepreneurial spirt and comfort with ambiguity, have a proven ability to collaborate on teams, and possess strong analytical, data analysis, and creative problem-solving skills. The Initiative is committed to racial equity, building a diverse and inclusive team, and recruiting candidates committed to these ideals. Applications are due by EOD on Wednesday, September 29th.

NOTE: unlike the other positions, this is only for the Fall 2021

Project Description:‍

Blight, neighborhood decline, and property distress are detrimental to the physical and social health of individuals and the economic and social well-being of communities. These are complex problems requiring a holistic approach. This project will support the documentation of lessons learned from a New York state focused program and other efforts, with the goal of creating a practical, user-oriented, and problem-focused guide for city leaders, practitioners, students, and educators seeking to better diagnose and ultimately address the cause and issues associated with distressed properties and neighborhood decline.‍

Tasks and Deliverables:

The Research Assistant will support the project team to:

  • Conduct background and desk research on data sources, tools, techniques, and promising practices that have been effective in diagnosing and addressing neighborhood decline and property distress
  • Provide substantial support in drafting text, creating data visualizations, and other graphics
  • Support and participate in interviews and focus groups with city leaders and prospective users to solicit input and feedback
  • Participate in regular remote check-ins with the broader research team

Desired Qualifications and Experience:

  • Strong research skills
  • Strong communication skills, especially written
  • Comfort with ambiguity and a willingness to experiment with different problem-solving approaches
  • Flexible schedule, ability to manage multiple tasks efficiently; good time-management skills
  • Persistent work ethic and self-discipline to stay on task
  • Comfort with working independently
  • Experience or familiarity with urban and housing policy and/or municipal government and related stakeholders is preferred, but not required
